column1: Before 1 May 2020, will China reduce or remove any tariffs imposed on U.S. yellow soybeans?
column6: ['Business', 'Economic Policy']

Bumping up to 91%. Recent articles such as the Foreign Policy article on 14 Feb below state that China "cut" tariffs on soybeans, but others like the CNBC via Reuters and FX Street on 17 and 18 Feb reported that China is granting tariff exemptions on soybeans. There seems to be some confusion on the exact status of the tariffs. If anyone is seeing anything different, let me know.
China is too shrewd to do this before the election. I think they hold the line on this.

China will be forced to concede in the trade war due to the impact of Coronavirus. However, it is still possible that nationalistic pride, muscle flexing, and China’s ability to insularise will triumph over economic necessity. The added potential of US soybeans being more available than typically globally due to climate change may make it more than economic necessity too.

This is my initial forecast for this question. Starting at 90% due to the two articles below that others have cited. I assess that the coronavirus strongly incentivizes China to work with the U.S. on reducing/removing tariffs to minimize the economic impact. I am unsure if China has fully removed the soybean tariff as stated in the Foreign Policy link below or has agreed that they will do it.

The tariff cut on soybeans has taken effect as of yesterday: "The phase one U.S.-China trade deal enters into force...United States cutting tariffs on $120 billion of Chinese goods in half and China reciprocating on $75 billion of U.S. goods, including cars, crude oil, and soybeans [1].
Increasing estimate due to the possibility that impending soybean tariff changes may not be solely enacted through exemptions and waivers.
Staying at 90%, but wanted to share a great source: https://www.agriculture.com/markets/newswire/grains-soybeans-firm-turning-up-on-prospects-for-chinese-export-demand

Updating (raising) my forecast. Found a different source (https://kiwaradio.com/ag-news/china-to-cut-tariffs-on-u-s-imports-on-february-14th/) that clarifies China's plan is in fact to cut tariffs on 14 Feb. That it is indeed a cut in tariffs means that this meets this question's criteria. I expect this question to close out on 14 Feb when China puts these changes in place. With this source clarifying the situation, increasing the odds of this happening by 30% from previous assessment. Very small probability that China changes its mind in the next 24 hrs.
Providing a lower forecast than team consensus and crowd forecast as waivers were used to reduce tariffs on 6 February vice an actual reduction.

The 6 Feb 2020 news that China cut tariffs from 30% to 27.5% appears to be through tariff waivers (https://www.agweb.com/article/soybeans-nudge-higher-after-china-makes-small-tariff-cut), so per the instructions above, this question is not yet resolved. INCREASING the odds that China will actually make permanent cuts is the fact that the US and China are progressing with a multi-phase trade deal where both sides are indicating willingness to compromise; also, Brazil's current bumper crop means that Brazil beans are going to be cheaper, so it may actually cost China nothing to lower tariffs on US products because they're not competitive anyway yet it will show a measure of goodwill in the trade war. Thus, it's more likely than not China will take advantage of this situation and permanently reduce the July 2018 soybean tariffs (though probably not by much).

According to Bloomberg.com on Feb 6th (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-06/china-to-halve-tariffs-on-75-billion-u-s-goods-from-feb-14), January 15th deal cuts tariffs on soybeans from 30% to 27.5%. Cuts are effective on Feb 14th. Keeping a 5% margin in case Coronavirus causes a delay, however even if it does I don't see it extending for 2.5 months.
I believe the coronavirus will so inpact Ch8na that they will need the imports.
On February 6, China announced would reduce tariffs on products including soybeans. Set to go into effect on February 14th,
I did not see this coming. But now adjusting in light of the new evidence.

How Chinese tariffs on U.S. imports will stand after February 14 cuts. \ Aizhu, Xu, Patton, Daly, Singh and Gu (2020). Feb.6, stated that: \ BEIJING/SINGAPORE (Reuters) - China is preparing to halve the extra tariffs on U.S goods that went into effect last September, including on crude oil, soybeans, pork and beef (Para. 1). \ It will see total tariffs on soybeans fall to 27.5% from 30%, total duties on pork drop to 55% from 60% and those on beef do down to 30% from 35%. Tariffs for U.S. crude oil, which was first targeted in September, will be reduced to 2.5% from 5% (Para. 4). \ SOYBEANS The Chinese government has given tariff exemptions to some U.S. soybean imports. In 2019, China brought in 16.94 million tonnes of U.S. soybeans, edging up from 16.6 million tonnes in 2018, when shipments nearly halved from the previous year due to the trade dispute. The Chinese government has given tariff exemptions to some U.S. soybean imports. \ Reference \ Aizhu, C., Xu, M., Patton, D., Daly, T., Singh, S. & Gu, H. (2020). How Chinese tariffs on U.S. imports will stand after February 14 cuts. Reuters. Business News. Feb.6, 2020. Retrieved form https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trade-china-commoditiestariffs-fa-idUSKBN2001XF \ Han, M., Lung, N., Chen, T., Niu, S. & Mohsin, S. (2020). China to Cut Tariffs 50% on U.S. Goods Spelled Out in Deal. Bloomberg News. Economics. February 6, 2020. Retrieved from https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-06/china-to-halve-tariffs-on-75-billion-u-s-goods-from-feb-14

Before 1 May 2020, will China reduce or remove any tariffs imposed on U.S. yellow soybeans? Not clear if this is a permanent reduction or a waiver. Hattip to @JC4841 for an excellent post.

Multiple news outlets reporting this morning a Chinese Ministry of Finance statement regarding reduction in tariffs on US goods. The specific reduction in soybean tariffs is a reduction from 30% to 27.5%. It is said to go into effect Feb 14 2020.
China announcement this AM

Before 1 May 2020, will China reduce or remove any tariffs imposed on U.S. yellow soybeans? I agree with the logic put forward by @dlaiocean and @JC4841 - zero at this juncture. This is a trade issue and doubtful there will be progress thru May as there are other more pressing issues.

It depends on the coronavirus and it's wider impact. The Chinese government will want to ease the unrest of the people or at the very least not give them another problem ie increase in price of a staple food if the death rate remains low there may be internal scapegoating. If it increases the tariff will reduce.
China will be significantly affected by the Wuhan coronavirus.
I lost track of this question and wasn’t following the news

China's economic growth already began to slow in 2019. SARS, which was less infectious but more lethal, resulted in more than a 1% reduction in GDP. nCoV, though less lethal, appears to be much more infectious and will likely result in overall more deaths. China will likely be unable to contain the nCoV outbreak. The regional travel bans affect not only ordinary citizens but also livestock & poultry farmers. These farmers can neither longer bring their animals to market nor can they buy feed to keep them alive. If this continues, China's stability may be threatened by rural unrest. By reducing or eliminating tariffs on US soybeans, China will appear to be help farmers.
Reduced probability - China has a much more urgent crisis (corona virus outbreak) to deal with right now and in the near future.

China officials on Dec 7, 2019 confirmed that it will waive import tariffs for some soybeans and pork shipments from the United States, as the two sides try to thrash out a broader agreement to defuse their protracted trade war.

Absorbing the question more closely and rereading my prior rationale - together they make me feel I did only a cursory consideration of the question. In particular, exemptions and waivers will not count towards this question. And waivers of tariffs seemed central to me to how the Chinese government will bring in soybeans from the US without breaking those importers' P&L. Given US tariffs are staying in place through the 2020 election, and this matter having an established tit-for-tat methodology - I see nothing that compels China to feel the need to actually reduce tariffs. And an early reduction of tariff broadcasts, without near-certain reciprocity by the US, would, to me, Chinese bargaining weakness. So a low single-digit possibility seems appropriate.
Further drop in forecast.

A reduction or removal of US (yellow) soybeans is highly unlikely as there were no substantive arrangements nor any indication that tariffs would be rolled back in phase 1 of the US-China trade deal. Separately, Brazil has emerged as significant exporter of soybeans to China - helping offset the need for the reduction or removal of tariffs, at least in the short-term.
China is not going to move

The phase 1 trade deal between the US and China makes no provisions for the rolling back of the tariffs imposed by the US on Chinese products, or the retaliatory tariffs imposed by China, including those on yellow soybeans. As China has new soybean contracts with Brazil there is little supply side rationale for the Chinese to remove tariffs imposed in retaliation for the US tariffs. The US President will not cave on the tariff issue at this point as doing so would be to loose the trade war we claimed would be so easy to win.

I will change back to 100 when or If I get an email reply to the clarification of the contractual agreement listing Soybean with 2 year term TRQ mechanism that allows a set amount, of specific products to be imported at a low or zero rate of duty. TRQ are not listed in the do not count towards reductions i.e. Tariffs exemptions and waivers would not count toward the resolution of the question.

Furthermore, Asians seem very sensitive to "face," a president leader under impeachment would seem to have little "face."

the will not remove the us yellow soybeans tariffs as they are investing and pushing to find other sources of soil i other country like Brazil and Africa

Acknowledging a mistake. Maybe.

Phase 1 agreement does not mention reduction and removal of tariffs. You can download and read the full document here (1). It is unlikely more trade agreements will happen before the election. Reducing the probability.

Agricultural products are an important part of the Phase 1 trade deal, yet the details do not direct China to alter their tariff structure. While on the long list of agricultural goods that may be part of basket of purchases that fulfills Chinese commitments, only wheat, rice, and corn are subject to a specific tariff quota commitment. https://ustr.gov/sites/default/files/files/agreements/phase%20one%20agreement/Economic_And_Trade_Agreement_Between_The_United_States_And_China_Text.pdf

@Si-Fi's excellent rationale, and especially the observation that the US soy growing season ended in November, so there's no soy supply at stake until after May 2020 anyway, leads me to drop my estimate even further.

While there is not direct language referring to specific tariffs on Soybean stated, the contractual obligation to purchase Soybean exists specifically outlines in Section 6 Agriculture 9 Oilseeds HS Code Product Description, 1201 Soybeans, whether or not broken (PDF Pg.69) page 6-17 of the Agreement.
Further reducing my forecast from 27% Yes to 9% Yes.

The text of the agreement contains no commitment to remove or lower tariffs, and in fact uses the word "tariff" only twice! It just says China will buy $12.5b in 2020 and 19.5b in 2021 in agricultural goods over and above the 2017 level (not $40b in additional agricultural goods, the number that is getting thrown around but seems to have no basis in fact). I think that China will not lower tariffs, and will just use TRQs to allow imports to hit their purchase quotas. IE what I've been saying the whole time.
Changing forecast as there is no real agreement concerning yellow soya beans.

The Phase One deal did not include tariff reductions. “There are no other oral or written agreements between the United States and China on these matters, and there is no agreement for future reduction in tariffs. Any rumors to the contrary are categorically false,” they said. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trade-china-tariffs/u-s-china-have-no-agreement-for-future-tariff-reductions-lighthizer-mnuchin-idUSKBN1ZD2PK

Coming down since the phase 1 deal did not include commitments. I don’t think there will be major developments between now and Phase II. That being said, I think there is still a risk of the Trump administration requiring Chinese tariff reductions being needed to start Phase II negotiations
Coming down markedly. Agreement to purchase more <> reduce/remove tariffs.

Phase One of the trade deal was just signed today, so there is hope that Phase Two would be signed before 1 May and that may remove the subject tariffs, however without details of the agreement, this is not a certainty as of yet (https://www.dtnpf.com/agriculture/web/ag/news/world-policy/article/2019/12/13/phase-one-us-china-agreement-large). With the upcoming election, there is some US pressure to resolve the trade dispute, thus I've assigned a greater than 50% chance.

The decision not to include a quid pro quo reduction of Soybean tariffs in the phase one agreement has convinced me that China will only waive tariffs in the near term and keep this card for later "phase two" negotiations. The Chinese could remove or reduce tariffs on the US, but large orders from last fall have already had tariffs waived and South American soybean crop will start peaking in late spring. By retaining the tariff in place, it allows the Chinese to keep the soybean card in the deck for a longer term.

With several other tariffs in place that can be played or eliminated as a sign of good faith, soybeans will be close to the end of the items that would have tariffs removed or reduced. Soybeans are a real hurting point for farmers in the US (mainly Republican voters) which gives the Chinese Government a lot of leverage with them in the current tariff war.

US to Lift China Currency Manipulator Tag Ahead of Trade Deal (Bloomberg) President Trump’s administration plans to lift its designation of China as a currency manipulator, people familiar with the matter said. The Treasury Department will make the move in a semi-annual report, expected to be released soon, after being delayed as the U.S. and China finalize a “phase one” trade pact, the sources said. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin in August first formally labeled China a currency-manipulator. That prompted authorities in Beijing to increase transparency around how they manage the yuan. Some of that data has provided support for Treasury’s view that the People’s Bank of China engages in competitive devaluations of its currency, the people said. The administration had at one point considered maintaining the label and instead announcing it would monitor the yuan with the possibility of lifting the designation in August of this year, according to the people. ——————- COMMENT: Keeping the same for now. I’m not sure President Xi will be moved to tears by the magnanimous act of trust!
Back to level of first forecast - valued daily news to much.

Soybean is an important weapon in China's trade war with the U.S. It is the top U.S. export to China, constituting about 60% of the US exports to China (1). It is unlikely that China will give up this weapon before the ending of the trade war with the U.S.

When Trump declared that a [Phase One deal had been struck with China](https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2019/10/17/trump-says-china-will-buy-billion-year-us-agriculture-thats-not-what-china-says/) in October he said that China would be buying $40 to $50 billion in U.S. agricultural products. However, no time frame has been given (is this over multiple years?) and the details for Phase One are still being hammered out. If China has stepped up its soybean purchases or if the market believes that it will there should have been a rebound in its price. Unfortunately, it seemed to peak right after Phase One was announced and has recently gone on a skid to under $9 per bushel. President Trump claimed that he struck a [“phase one” trade deal with China](https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2019/10/11/us-stocks-poised-big-bounce-expectations-grow-us-china-trade-deal/?tid=lk_inline_manual_2) on Friday and that the Chinese agreed to massive purchases of U.S. farm products. But nearly a week has passed, and China has not confirmed that critical piece of the agreement. According to the White House, a key part of Trump’s initial deal is China’s commitment to buy $40 billion to $50 billion worth of U.S. agricultural products. But nothing was written on paper, and China’s Commerce Ministry would [not confirm that figure](https://www.cnbc.com/2019/10/17/china-says-us-must-cancel-new-tariffs-for-ultimate-trade-deal.html) Thursday, saying instead purchases would be made according to Chinese market needs. As Trump and Chinese Vice Premier Liu He stood face to face in the Oval Office on Friday, a reporter asked whether the agreement was for $40 billion to $50 billion in purchases every year. Trump turned to Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and asked him to “define that, please.” “It will scale up to an annual figure. Yes,” said Mnuchin, who later added it would hit that higher level “within the second year." A spokeswoman for the U.S. trade representative said Thursday that China had committed to $40 billion to $50 billion a year, “scaling up over two years,” implying purchases would be significantly higher by 2021. ========== China is picking up soybean cargoes in Brazil, dashing hopes for big American sales immediately after a partial trade deal is signed with the U.S. next week, according to people familiar with the matter. Private buyers from China have purchased about 10 cargoes from the South American nation so far this week, said the people, who asked not to be identified because the deals are private. Most of the soybeans are for shipments from January through April, the people said. https://finance.yahoo.com/news/china-purchases-brazilian-soybeans-trade-182419133.html ================ COMMENTS: I may have to revise this, but for now I can’t have full faith in Trump’s big statements

We don't know what it is in the Phase 1 deal (yet), it could simply agree to "no further increases" or a return to conditions on some previous date, or a commitment to further improvement in relations, etc. But given that increased agricultural purchases are reportedly part of the deal, it would make sense they would lower the cost to their own consumers.

China will likely use exemptions and waivers to negotiate in short term.

China imports soybeans to feed its livestock, primarily swine. In 2019 significant number of swine were culled due to fever. Consequently the domestic demand for soybean has declined in China. China has also begun import of soybeans from Brazil and increased domestic production to meet the demand. Higher import tariff on US soybeans would not yield much revenue because of the reduced imports. Also higher tariffs would increase cost to domestic farmers already reeling under the impact of swine fever. A reduction in tariff is beneficial to China and would go a long way in appeasing Trump who has a substantial support base among US soy farmers. A reduction in tariff need not result in higher imports from US farmers though. So net gain would be China's favour. Hence I expect China to reduce tariff on US soybeans before May 2020.

I'll start at 50/50 and then look at lowering over time.
